Profile: Vbai Plan Definition

title: Pediatrics Cohort Protcol

status: active

date: 2023-04-28

publisher: KinD Lab

contact: KinD Lab: http://fhir.kindlab.sickkids.ca

description: This is a plandefinition for Pediatrics cohort protocol

action

prefix: 1.1

title: Consent

description: Ask participant for consent

priority: routine

Participants

-Type
*patient

Actions

-PrefixTitleDescriptionPriority
*1.1.1Login for clinicianLogin for clinicianroutine
*1.1.2Enroll participantEnroll participantroutine
*1.1.1Retrieve ConsentBefore you participate in this study, we need your consent. The consent gives you information of what to expect and what is required from you for this study. It will also give you information about how your data will be shared. You have options to read the consent, watch the video consent, or do both before you decide to give your electronic consent.routine

action

prefix: 1.2

title: Demographics

description: Gather Demographics that need to be collected

priority: routine

definition: Demographic Surveys2

action

prefix: 1.3

title: Acoustic Tasks

description: Acoustic tasks across all cohorts

priority: routine

Actions

-PrefixTitleDescriptionPriority
*1.3.1Perform Acoustic tasksAudio check (Audio check: Before we start, let’s test your microphone. Click on the Start button below and say something out loud like “Testing 1, 2, 3”. Recording will stop automatically after 5 seconds. Click Play to hear your recording. If you hear background noise, please go to a quieter place and try again by selecting Redo Recording. If it sounds good, continue.routine
*1.3 Task 1Prolonged vowel: ​Count to 3 and say “e” for 5 seconds This task helps us analyze features in your voiceroutine
*1.3 Task 2Maximum phonation time: Say /e/ (max. phonation time ): 'Using your normal voice, take a deep breath and say /e/' until you run completely out of air (click stop when you run out of air)'. (need to ask for this task twice!) This tasks helps us analyze the way your respiration is connected to your voiceroutine
*1.3 Task 3Glides: “Using the sound “e”, glide from your lowest pitch possible to the highest pitch possible. Rest, take a breath and then glide from your highest pitch possible to the lowest pitch possible”This task helps us understand how your vocal folds stretchroutine
*1.3 Task 4Rainbow passage : 'Read the following passage using your normal voice:' Short Rainbow passage: '￼Read the following passage using your normal voice: When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow. The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors. These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon. There is, according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end. This is a standardized passage that contains all the important sounds of the English languageroutine
*1.3 Task 5Task 5: Cape-V Sentences: “Read these sentences using your normal voice”  The blue spot is on the key again, How hard did he hit him?, We were away a year ago, We eat eggs every easter, My momma makes lemon muffins, Peter will keep at the peak This is a standardized passage that contains all the important sounds of the English languageroutine
*1.3 Task 6 Task 6: Caterpillar passage 'Read the following passage using your normal voice:' Caterpillar passage: Do you like amusement parks? Well, I sure do. To amuse myself, I went twice last spring. My most MEMORABLE moment was riding on the Caterpillar, which is a gigantic rollercoaster high above the ground. When I saw how high the Caterpillar rose into the bright blue sky I knew it was for me. After waiting in line for thirty minutes, I made it to the front where the man measured my height to see if I was tall enough. I gave the man my coins, asked for change, and jumped on the cart. Tick, tick, tick, the Caterpillar climbed slowly up the tracks. It went SO high I could see the parking lot. Boy was I SCARED! I thought to myself, “There’s no turning back now.” People were so scared they screamed as we swiftly zoomed fast, fast, and faster along the tracks. As quickly as it started, the Caterpillar came to a stop. Unfortunately, it was time to pack the car and drive home. That night I dreamt of the wild ride on the Caterpillar. Taking a trip to the amusement park and riding on the Caterpillar was my MOST memorable moment ever! This is a standardized passage that contains all the important words to test your articulationroutine
*1.3 Task 7Task 7: ​￼​Diadocokinesis:[Text Wrapping Break]  Say the syllables as they appear on your screen – Pa / Ta / Ka, Now record yourself repeating the syllable /PA/ as fast as possible 10 times, Record yourself repeating the syllable /TA/ as fast as possible 10 times, Record yourself repeating the syllable /KA/ as fast as possible 10 times, Now repeat the work /Pataka/ as fast as possible 10 times, Now repeat the word /buttercup/ as fast as possible 10 times This task tests the way you can articulate the sounds and can gives neurological queuesroutine
*1.3 Task 8Task 8: Free speech: Open ended question (generic) chose 1-2  “This section is meant to hear you speak freely by answering an open ended question” “Please answer the following questions and record your answer. Keep talking until the time stops” (leave for 30 seconds)- Options:   Can you talk to us about why you are interested by this study? Who told you about it? Why is it meaningful or valuable to you? How do you think it will help patients in the future?, Can you tell us a little bit about your health condition? When did it start, what kind of symptoms have you had and for how long? Tell us how you are managing it and how you are doing?​​​, ​​​​ How would you get from where you are now to the grocery store? Explain with as much detail as possible.​​​​​​​ routine
*1.3 Task 9Task 9: Respiration and cough:   'Respiratory sounds can also provide information on your health, let’s record them” -  First, let's hear you breath comfortably for 30 seconds, After pressing on record, take 5 big breaths in and out through your nose with your mouth closed, After pressing record, cough 5 times, Now try again (need that task twice)  routine
*1.3 Task 10Picture description: “You will be shown a picture, please describe what you see in your own words. You can keep talking until the time runs out” (1 min) routine
*1.3 Task 11Task 11: Story Recall: “You are given a text. Read the text so you familiarize yourself with it. You have up to 5 minutes to read it as many times as you want. When you are ready, you will be asked to recall the story. This can be in your own words.”  -  You wished to know all about my grandfather. Well, he is nearly ninety-three years old. He dresses himself in an ancient black frock coat, usually minus several buttons; yet he still thinks as swiftly as ever. A long, flowing beard clings to his chin, giving those who observe him a pronounced feeling of the utmost respect. When he speaks his voice is just a bit cracked and quivers a trifle. Twice each day he plays skillfully and with zest upon our small organ. Except in the winter when the ooze or snow or ice prevents, he slowly takes a short walk in the open air each day. We have often urged him to walk more and smoke less, but he always answers, “Banana Oil!” Grandfather likes to be modern in his language.  routine

title: PMHX and List of Confounders

priority: routine

prefix: 1.5

priority: routine

Actions

-PrefixTitleDescriptionPriorityDefinition[x]

action

prefix: 1.6

title: Feedback Pilot

description: Questions for feedback for pilot​

priority: routine

action

prefix: B

title: Part B Peds

description: Tasks specific to Peds cohort ​

priority: routine

Actions

-PrefixTitleDescription
*B.1 Task 1Produce sustained /a/ sound  a) App demonstration first  b) At a comfortable pitch and volume using a normal speaking voice  C) Duration: 4 seconds 
*B.1 Task 2Diadochokinetic task with “patty-cake”Record the time that it takes to repeat the syllables  'pat' 10 times  'tee' 10 times  'cake' 10 times  Repeat whole word as fast as possible for 30 seconds 
*B.1 Task 3Recite the alphabet (ABC’s)Duration: until complete, or for 60 seconds
*B.1 Task 4Count as high as you canDuration: 60 seconds 
*B.1 Task 5Name daily life picturesApp prompts child to name 36 randomly-selected pictures Duration of task: 60 seconds Modification if unable to see: repeat after adult
*B.1 Task 6Read or repeat CAPE-V sentences:Please read the following sentences one at a time, as if you were speaking to somebody in a real conversation.” If the individual has difficulty reading, the clinician may ask him or her to repeat sentences after verbal examples. App to show sentences appearing one at a time.  “The blue spot is on the key again” “How hard did he hit him?”  “We were away a year ago” “We eat eggs every Easter” “My mama makes lemon jam” “Peter will keep at the peak”
*B.1 Task 7Read or repeat the Caterpillar Passage – in app, passage will appear one sentence at a time Do you like amusement parks? Well, I sure do. To amuse myself, I went twice last spring. My most MEMORABLE moment was riding on the Caterpillar, which is a gigantic roller coaster high above the ground. When I saw how high the Caterpillar rose into the bright blue sky I knew it was for me. After waiting in line for thirty minutes, I made it to the front where the man measured my height to see if I was tall enough. I gave the man my coins, asked for change, and jumped on the cart. Tick, tick, tick, the Caterpillar climbed slowly up the tracks. It went SO high I could see the parking lot. Boy was I SCARED! I thought to myself, “There’s no turning back now.” People were so scared they screamed as we swiftly zoomed fast, fast, and faster along the tracks. As quickly as it started, the Caterpillar came to a stop. Unfortunately, it was time to pack the car and drive home. That night I dreamt of the wild ride on the Caterpillar. Taking a trip to the amusement park and riding on the Caterpillar was my MOST memorable moment ever!”  Modification: recite passage sentence by sentence after adult
*B.1 Task 8Cued conversation: If child responds, record for 60 seconds and then end protocol   If preferred toy present:   “what is that?”  “what can it do?”  “does it make any sounds?”  “why do you like it?”  If preferred toy not present:   “What is your favorite animal?”  “what does it sound like?”  “what can it do?”   “why do you like it?”  If child does not respond, proceed to #9 
*B.1 Task 9Spontaneous vocalizations/cry sounds If preferred toy present:   “I like your toy! Does your toy have a name?”  “what does your toy say?”  “what does your toy do?” (parent encourages child to play with toy)  If preferred toy not present, bring out animal toys (barn setup):   Parent and child sit down together  Child picks up animal toys  Parent makes animal sounds with each toy the child picks up  Parent may also want to move animals around the barn scene if child not engaging with the toys and make noises with each animal they hold  Hopefully, this inspires child to vocalize, too  Record for 60 seconds and then end protocol

title: Pediatrics Cohort Protcol
description: This is a plandefinition for Pediatrics cohort protocol

action.title: Consent
action.description: Ask participant for consent

action.title: Login for clinician
action.description: Login for clinician

action.title: Enroll participant
action.description: Enroll participant

action.title: Retrieve Consent
action.description: Before you participate in this study, we need your consent. The consent gives you information of what to expect and what is required from you for this study. It will also give you information about how your data will be shared. You have options to read the consent, watch the video consent, or do both before you decide to give your electronic consent.

action.title: Demographics
action.description: Gather Demographics that need to be collected

action.title: Acoustic Tasks
action.description: Acoustic tasks across all cohorts

action.title: Perform Acoustic tasks
action.description: Audio check (Audio check: Before we start, let’s test your microphone. Click on the Start button below and say something out loud like “Testing 1, 2, 3”. Recording will stop automatically after 5 seconds. Click Play to hear your recording. If you hear background noise, please go to a quieter place and try again by selecting Redo Recording.  If it sounds good, continue.

action.title: Prolonged vowel: ​Count to 3 and say “e” for 5 seconds
action.description: This task helps us analyze features in your voice

action.title: Maximum phonation time: Say /e/  (max. phonation time ): 'Using your normal voice, take a deep breath and say /e/' until you run completely out of air (click stop when you run out of air)'. (need to ask for this task twice!)
action.description: This tasks helps us analyze the way your respiration is connected to your voice

action.title: Glides: “Using the sound “e”, glide from your lowest pitch possible to the highest pitch possible. Rest, take a breath and then glide from your highest pitch possible to the lowest pitch possible”
action.description: This task helps us understand how your vocal folds stretch

action.title: Rainbow passage :  'Read the following passage using your normal voice:' Short Rainbow passage: '￼Read the following passage using your normal voice: When the sunlight strikes raindrops in the air, they act as a prism and form a rainbow. The rainbow is a division of white light into many beautiful colors.  These take the shape of a long round arch, with its path high above, and its two ends apparently beyond the horizon. There is, according to legend, a boiling pot of gold at one end.
action.description: This is a standardized passage that contains all the important sounds of the English language

action.title:
Task 5: Cape-V Sentences: “Read these sentences using your normal voice” 
      The blue spot is on the key again,
      How hard did he hit him?,
      We were away a year ago,
      We eat eggs every easter,
      My momma makes lemon muffins,
      Peter will keep at the peak
action.description: This is a standardized passage that contains all the important sounds of the English language

action.title: Task 6: Caterpillar passage 'Read the following passage using your normal voice:' Caterpillar passage: Do you like amusement parks? Well, I sure do. To amuse myself, I went twice last spring. My most MEMORABLE moment was riding on the Caterpillar, which is a gigantic rollercoaster high above the ground. When I saw how high the Caterpillar rose into the bright blue sky I knew it was for me. After waiting in line for thirty minutes, I made it to the front where the man measured my height to see if I was tall enough. I gave the man my coins, asked for change, and jumped on the cart. Tick, tick, tick, the Caterpillar climbed slowly up the tracks. It went SO high I could see the parking lot. Boy was I SCARED! I thought to myself, “There’s no turning back now.” People were so scared they screamed as we swiftly zoomed fast, fast, and faster along the tracks. As quickly as it started, the Caterpillar came to a stop. Unfortunately, it was time to pack the car and drive home. That night I dreamt of the wild ride on the Caterpillar. Taking a trip to the amusement park and riding on the Caterpillar was my MOST memorable moment ever!
action.description: This is a standardized passage that contains all the important words to test your articulation

action.title:
Task 7: ​￼​Diadocokinesis:[Text Wrapping Break] 
    Say the syllables as they appear on your screen – Pa / Ta / Ka,
    Now record yourself repeating the syllable /PA/ as fast as possible 10 times,
    Record yourself repeating the syllable /TA/ as fast as possible 10 times,
    Record yourself repeating the syllable /KA/ as fast as possible 10 times,
    Now repeat the work /Pataka/ as fast as possible 10 times,
    Now repeat the word /buttercup/ as fast as possible 10 times
action.description: This task tests the way you can articulate the sounds and can gives neurological queues

action.title:
Task 8: Free speech: Open ended question (generic) chose 1-2 
 “This section is meant to hear you speak freely by answering an open ended question” “Please answer the following questions and record your answer. Keep talking until the time stops” (leave for 30 seconds)- Options:  

    Can you talk to us about why you are interested by this study? Who told you about it? Why is it meaningful or valuable to you? How do you think it will help patients in the future?,

    Can you tell us a little bit about your health condition? When did it start, what kind of symptoms have you had and for how long? Tell us how you are managing it and how you are doing?​​​,

​​​​    How would you get from where you are now to the grocery store? Explain with as much detail as possible.​​​​​​​

Task 9: Respiration and cough:  
'Respiratory sounds can also provide information on your health, let’s record them” - 

First, let's hear you breath comfortably for 30 seconds,
After pressing on record, take 5 big breaths in and out through your nose with your mouth closed,
After pressing record, cough 5 times,
Now try again (need that task twice)
Picture description: “You will be shown a picture, please describe what you see in your own words. You can keep talking until the time runs out” (1 min)

Task 11: Story Recall:  “You are given a text. Read the text so you familiarize yourself with it. You have up to 5 minutes to read it as many times as you want. When you are ready, you will be asked to recall the story. This can be in your own words.” 

-  You wished to know all about my grandfather. Well, he is nearly ninety-three years old. He dresses himself in an ancient black frock coat, usually minus several buttons; yet he still thinks as swiftly as ever. A long, flowing beard clings to his chin, giving those who observe him a pronounced feeling of the utmost respect. When he speaks his voice is just a bit cracked and quivers a trifle. Twice each day he plays skillfully and with zest upon our small organ. Except in the winter when the ooze or snow or ice prevents, he slowly takes a short walk in the open air each day. We have often urged him to walk more and smoke less, but he always answers, “Banana Oil!” Grandfather likes to be modern in his language.
PMHX and List of Confounders
action.description: Gather PMHx and Cofounders that need to be collected

action.title: Questionnaires
action.description: Administer validated questionnaires

action.title: PHQ9 Questionniare
action.description: Administer PHQ9 Questionnaire

action.title: GAD7 Questionniare
action.description: Administer GAD7 Questionnaire

action.title: Feedback Pilot
action.description: Questions for feedback for pilot​

action.title: Part B Peds
action.description: Tasks specific to Peds cohort ​

action.title: Produce sustained /a/ sound
action.description:
a) App demonstration first 

    b) At a comfortable pitch and volume using a normal speaking voice 

    C) Duration: 4 seconds

action.title: Diadochokinetic task with “patty-cake”
action.description:
Record the time that it takes to repeat the syllables 
    'pat' 10 times 

    'tee' 10 times 

    'cake' 10 times 

    Repeat whole word as fast as possible for 30 seconds

action.title: Recite the alphabet (ABC’s)
action.description: Duration: until complete, or for 60 seconds

action.title: Count as high as you can
action.description: Duration: 60 seconds

action.title: Name daily life pictures
action.description:
App prompts child to name 36 randomly-selected pictures

    Duration of task: 60 seconds

    Modification if unable to see: repeat after adult

action.title: Read or repeat CAPE-V sentences:
action.description:
Please read the following sentences one at a time, as if you were speaking to somebody in a real conversation.” If the individual has difficulty reading, the clinician may ask him or her to repeat sentences after verbal examples. App to show sentences appearing one at a time. 

    “The blue spot is on the key again”

    “How hard did he hit him?” 

    “We were away a year ago”

    “We eat eggs every Easter”

    “My mama makes lemon jam”

    “Peter will keep at the peak”

action.title: Read or repeat the Caterpillar Passage – in app, passage will appear one sentence at a time
action.description:
Do you like amusement parks? Well, I sure do. To amuse myself, I went twice last spring. My most MEMORABLE moment was riding on the Caterpillar, which is a gigantic roller coaster high above the ground. When I saw how high the Caterpillar rose into the bright blue sky I knew it was for me. After waiting in line for thirty minutes, I made it to the front where the man measured my height to see if I was tall enough. I gave the man my coins, asked for change, and jumped on the cart. Tick, tick, tick, the Caterpillar climbed slowly up the tracks. It went SO high I could see the parking lot. Boy was I SCARED! I thought to myself, “There’s no turning back now.” People were so scared they screamed as we swiftly zoomed fast, fast, and faster along the tracks. As quickly as it started, the Caterpillar came to a stop. Unfortunately, it was time to pack the car and drive home. That night I dreamt of the wild ride on the Caterpillar. Taking a trip to the amusement park and riding on the Caterpillar was my MOST memorable moment ever!” 
    Modification: recite passage sentence by sentence after adult

action.title: Cued conversation:
action.description:
If child responds, record for 60 seconds and then end protocol  
    If preferred toy present:  

    “what is that?” 

    “what can it do?” 

    “does it make any sounds?” 

    “why do you like it?” 

If preferred toy not present:  

    “What is your favorite animal?” 

    “what does it sound like?” 

    “what can it do?”  

    “why do you like it?” 

If child does not respond, proceed to #9

action.title: Spontaneous vocalizations/cry sounds
action.description:
If preferred toy present:  

    “I like your toy! Does your toy have a name?” 

    “what does your toy say?” 

    “what does your toy do?” (parent encourages child to play with toy) 

    If preferred toy not present, bring out animal toys (barn setup):  

    Parent and child sit down together 

    Child picks up animal toys 

    Parent makes animal sounds with each toy the child picks up 

Parent may also want to move animals around the barn scene if child not engaging with the toys and make noises with each animal they hold 

    Hopefully, this inspires child to vocalize, too 

Record for 60 seconds and then end protocol
